clinical_study.brief_title: Home Centered Comprehensive Care (HCCC) for Children With Asthma
clinical_study.official_title: Home-Centered Comprehensive Care (HCCC) for Children With Severe Asthma: A Pilot Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

collaborator.agency: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess whether comprehensive care enhanced with new technology to optimize asthma care in the home (using both a special sensor to track inhaler use and a hand-held PIKO-1 device to assess patients' forced expiratory volume in the 1st second [FEV1]) is effective in reducing total days when medical treatment is given outside the home (in clinic, emergency department, or hospital) among children with severe asthma receiving comprehensive care.

primary_outcome.description: Total number of days when medical treatment was given outside the home (in a clinic, ED, or hospital). Measured by parent report every 3 months for both groups.

secondary_outcome.description: Total number of days of school missed with respiratory illnesses (including respiratory infections with symptoms aggravated by asthma). Measured by parental report on questionnaires given every 3 months
Improve routine pulmonary function tests one year after enrollment by measuring PFTs during every clinic visit (for both groups), and by hand-held PFT device (PiKo-only for intervention group)
Parental satisfaction among groups using CAHPS survey annually.

secondary_outcome.measure: Total costs of clinic and hospital care
secondary_outcome.description: Total cost of clinic and hospital cost measured using billing information.
Physician Services cost to reimbursement measured using UT claims data.

intervention.description: Standard comprehensive care at High Risk Children's Clinic

standard comprehensive care at the High Risk Children's Clinic enhaced with new technologies: If between 2 and 5 years old--> will receive Home-centered comprehensive care with the propeller 5 and above--> will receive home-centered comprehensive care with propeller and PIKO

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children with severe asthma (poorly controlled by NIH guidelines ) who meet the inclusion criteria for HRCC (>3 ED visits, >2 hospitalizations, or >1 pediatric ICU admission in past as well as a >50% estimated risk of hospitalization in next yr).
Exclusion Criteria:
- other major lung disease (e.g. cystic fibrosis or bronchopulmonary dysplasia) or neuromuscular impairment.
